title: Roadmap
content:
Roadmap# A rough sketch where this could be going.
Allow learning from many language to many other languages (e.g. enable a native French speaker to learn Swahili) Create minimal pair decks to learn pronunciation Create language specific IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet) decks for learning what the IPA symbols mean and what sounds they encode to enable learners to efficiently use a dictionary Create decks for learning the 625 basic words in any language Create cards for learning vocabulary and grammatical structures according to levels (e.g. A1, A2, B1, …) Create advanced monolingual decks e.g. for learning what pecuniary or peevish mean in English

title: Available Decks
content:
Available Decks# All decks are free, open source, and actively developed. Each deck includes audio pronunciation, IPA transcriptions, and four card types to reinforce learning.
Note: All decks are currently in development and may not yet contain all 625 words. See individual deck pages for current status.
625 Words Decks# Learn the most important 625 words in your target language using spaced repetition.
If you speak English and want to learn …# French | 625 Words German | 625 Words Italian | 625 Words Portuguese | 625 Words Spanish | 625 Words Wenn du Deutsch sprichst und … lernen möchtest# Englisch | 625 Wörter Französisch | 625 Wörter Spanisch | 625 Wörter Si hablas español y quieres aprender …# Alemán | 625 palabras Inglés | 625 palabras Minimal Pairs Decks# Learn to distinguish similar-sounding phonemes in your target language.
German Minimal Pairs (for English speakers) About These Decks# Each deck includes:
Audio: Native speaker pronunciation for every word IPA: International Phonetic Alphabet transcriptions Four card types: Pronunciation, Listening, Reading, and Spelling Regular updates: Improvements and additions released frequently Open source: Licensed under permissive licenses for easy reuse All decks are available on GitHub Releases and AnkiWeb.

title: German | Minimal Pairs
content:
German | Minimal Pairs# Learn to distinguish German phonemes as an English speaker.
Note that this deck is not finished!
Check AnkiLangs.org for more decks and to help improving this deck.
Download deck
See Installation Instructions and Learning Tips.
What are Minimal Pairs?# Minimal pairs are pairs of words that differ in only one phoneme (sound), such as “Beet” (flowerbed) vs “Bett” (bed) in German. By practicing these pairs, you train your ear to distinguish similar sounds that may not exist in your native language.
This deck helps English speakers overcome common pronunciation and listening challenges in German by focusing on sounds that are easily confused.

title: Installation
content:
Installation# Installing a Deck# Download the .apkg file from the deck’s page Open Anki Go to File → Import Select the downloaded .apkg file Click “Import” The deck will be added to your collection and you can start studying immediately.
Updating a Deck# When a new version is released:
Download the new .apkg file Import it into Anki (same steps as above) Anki will update your deck while preserving your learning progress Your review history and card scheduling will be maintained during updates.
Installing Anki# If you don’t have Anki yet, check the official instructions for installing on Windows, macOS, Linux, Android, or iOS.

title: Learning Tips
content:
Learning Tips# Study Tips# Study consistently: Daily practice is more effective than long, infrequent sessions Speak out loud: For pronunciation cards, always speak the answer aloud Use the audio: Listen carefully to native pronunciation on all audio-enabled cards Don’t rush: Take time to recall the answer before revealing it Be honest: Mark cards as “Again” if you couldn’t recall the answer quickly Adjusting Deck Options# Avoid learning too many new cards per day because it might quickly become overwhelming. The default value of New cards/day of 20 is a good start.
We strongly encourage you activate burying to make your learning most efficient. Otherwise you may for example be asked to do Reading for a word that you just completed Pronunciation for, which makes it too easy. This would hurt your long term progress since a few weeks later you no longer have the Pronunciation context and will fail. Also in real-life situations when you need to read a word you lack that context.
Enabling FSRS (Free Spaced Repetition Scheduler) is also a good idea because it calculates more optimal review intervals.
See Anki’s documentation for detailed settings guidance.
Card Types# Most AnkiLangs decks use four complementary card types to help you master vocabulary:
Pronunciation# See the source language word and speak the target language word aloud. Focus on accurate pronunciation.
Listening# Hear the target language word and recall its meaning in the source language. Trains your listening comprehension.
Reading# See the target language word and recall its meaning in the source language. Trains your reading comprehension.
Spelling# See the source language word, hear the target language pronunciation, and type the target language word. Reinforces spelling and combines reading with listening.
Minimal Pairs Decks# For minimal pairs decks specifically:
Listen carefully: Focus on the subtle differences between the sounds Repeat out loud: After revealing the answer, practice speaking both words Use the audio repeatedly: Play each audio multiple times if needed Practice regularly: Daily short sessions are more effective than long, infrequent ones
